articles.headline: Start-Ups Work on Biotech Drugs for Pets
articles.snippet: Entrepreneurs hope to develop innovative drugs for dogs and cats like those that have revolutionized the treatment of diseases like cancer in people.
articles.abstract: Entrepreneurs hope to develop innovative drugs for dogs and cats like those that have revolutionized the treatment of diseases like cancer in people.
articles.lead_paragraph: Judging by some of the heavy action in the world of biotechnology, one could easily conclude that the industry is going to the dogs. Or cats, maybe.

articles.headline: In Tunnel War, Israeli Playbook Offers Few Ideas
articles.snippet: Though Israel knew about Hamas’s tunnels, it has been surprised by how the militant group trained its fighters to use them.
articles.abstract: Though Israel knew about Hamas’s tunnels, it has been surprised by how the militant group trained its fighters to use them.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israel entered its latest conflict with Hamas armed with a high-tech arsenal, real-time battlefield intelligence and strong domestic support for dealing a heavy blow to Hamas.

articles.headline: More Online Publishers Let Readers Fill the Space
articles.snippet: Media companies are adding technology that allows readers to upload digital material like links, text or video with varying levels of oversight.
articles.abstract: Media companies are adding technology that allows readers to upload digital material like links, text or video with varying levels of oversight.
articles.lead_paragraph: To most English speakers, “platform” is a noun. But among news organizations, it is quickly becoming a verb.

articles.headline: A Test for Ukraine in a City Retaken From Rebels
articles.snippet: In Slovyansk, a city of 80,000 that was a stronghold for pro-Russian rebels, Ukraine authorities have a difficult task ahead to shift the loyalties of residents to keep the peace.
articles.abstract: In Slovyansk, a city of 80,000 that was a stronghold for pro-Russian rebels, Ukraine authorities have a difficult task ahead to shift the loyalties of residents to keep the peace.
articles.lead_paragraph: SLOVYANSK, Ukraine — When Denis Bigunov, a civil servant, recently returned to work after a long break, he found three prisoner’s hoods wrapped in masking tape stashed in his office at City Hall, sinister mementos left behind by the pro-Russian rebels who controlled this eastern Ukrainian city for nearly three months.

articles.headline: California Asks: Should Doctors Face Drug Tests?
articles.snippet: A battle over a proposal, packed away in a broader initiative meant to raise the financial cap on medical malpractice awards, is being closely watched across the country.
articles.abstract: A battle over a proposal, packed away in a broader initiative meant to raise the financial cap on medical malpractice awards, is being closely watched across the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — At a time when random drug testing is part of the job for pilots, train operators, police officers and firefighters — to name a few — one high-profile line of work has managed to remain exempt: doctors.

articles.headline: Victims of Defective G.M. Ignition Switches Begin Filing Claims
articles.snippet: The process will ultimately help calculate how many people were killed or seriously hurt by the flawed switches.
articles.abstract: The process will ultimately help calculate how many people were killed or seriously hurt by the flawed switches.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — A fund General Motors put in place to compensate victims of accidents caused by its vehicles’ faulty ignition switches began accepting claims on Friday. The process will ultimately help calculate how many people were killed or seriously hurt by the deadly defect.

articles.headline: Congress Off for the Exits, but Few Cheer
articles.snippet: After a session in which both parties shared the blame for inaction on major issues, a five-week recess lies ahead.
articles.abstract: After a session in which both parties shared the blame for inaction on major issues, a five-week recess lies ahead.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House and Senate lawmakers scrambled to leave town on Friday night for a five-week recess, with a failure to address the refugee crisis at the southern border only the latest indignity in a year that may redefine congressional dysfunction.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Weisman and Ashley Parker

articles.headline: Missing Soldier Killed in Battle, Israel Confirms
articles.snippet: The Israeli military said the soldier who had been thought captured by Palestinian militants during a deadly clash on Friday was now considered to have been killed in battle.
articles.abstract: The Israeli military said the soldier who had been thought captured by Palestinian militants during a deadly clash on Friday was now considered to have been killed in battle.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The Israeli military said early Sunday morning that an officer thought to have been captured by Palestinian militants during a deadly clash Friday morning, which shattered a planned 72-hour cease-fire, was now considered to have been killed in battle.
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger and Jodi Rudoren

articles.headline: Big Banks Still a Risk
articles.snippet: A new study that assessed the value to banks of the implied guarantee by taxpayers raised more questions than it answered.
articles.abstract: A new study that assessed the value to banks of the implied guarantee by taxpayers raised more questions than it answered.
articles.lead_paragraph: Big bankers are usually good at arithmetic. But when it comes to assessing the benefits of their too-big-to-fail status, their calculators tend to go haywire.

articles.headline: $1,000 Hepatitis Pill Shows Why Fixing Health Costs Is So Hard
articles.snippet: Critics have raised an outcry over Sovaldi, a hepatitis C drug heralded as a breakthrough but costing $84,000 for a typical person’s total treatment.
articles.abstract: Critics have raised an outcry over Sovaldi, a hepatitis C drug heralded as a breakthrough but costing $84,000 for a typical person’s total treatment.
articles.lead_paragraph: A new drug for the liver disease hepatitis C is scaring people. Not because the drug is dangerous — it’s generally heralded as a genuine medical breakthrough — but because it costs $1,000 a pill and about $84,000 for a typical person’s total treatment.

articles.headline: No Longer Ignored, Evidence Solves Rape Cases Years Later
articles.snippet: Hundreds of thousands of kits from sexual assault cases have gone untested, but cities like Memphis and Detroit are beginning to test evidence and get results.
articles.abstract: Hundreds of thousands of kits from sexual assault cases have gone untested, but cities like Memphis and Detroit are beginning to test evidence and get results.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEMPHIS — Meaghan Ybos was 16 and had just arrived home from school when a man in a ski mask held a knife to her throat and raped her.

articles.headline: Newly Insured, Many Now Face Learning Curve
articles.snippet: The Affordable Care Act is reaching many people who have not had health insurance in years, if at all, and they are struggling to understand their policies.
articles.abstract: The Affordable Care Act is reaching many people who have not had health insurance in years, if at all, and they are struggling to understand their policies.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Advocates of the Affordable Care Act, focused until now on persuading people to buy health insurance, have moved to a crucial new phase: making sure the eight million Americans who did so understand their often complicated policies and use them properly.

articles.headline: Hope Dwindles for Hondurans Living in Peril
articles.snippet: Residents of Chamelecón, the most dangerous neighborhood in one of the most dangerous cities in the hemisphere, face a daily grind of murder and mayhem.
articles.abstract: Residents of Chamelecón, the most dangerous neighborhood in one of the most dangerous cities in the hemisphere, face a daily grind of murder and mayhem.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN PEDRO SULA, Honduras — The pastor came one afternoon to survey his church, or what was left of it: remnants of a “welcome” sign and a strip of Christmas garland still tacked to the wall.

articles.headline: U.S.-Russia Nuclear Deal Stalls as Tensions Over Ukraine Rise
articles.snippet: The growing confrontation between the United States and Russia has derailed an accord to expand collaboration on nuclear projects, including reciprocal visits to atomic sites by scientists.
articles.abstract: The growing confrontation between the United States and Russia has derailed an accord to expand collaboration on nuclear projects, including reciprocal visits to atomic sites by scientists.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The growing confrontation between Washington and Moscow over Ukraine has derailed a recent accord that promised one of the most expansive collaborations ever between the countries’ nuclear scientists, including reciprocal visits to atomic sites to work on projects ranging from energy to planetary defense.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and William J. Broad

articles.headline: How Facebook Sold You Krill Oil
articles.snippet: To grab some of TV’s ad dollars, the social network is trying to help advertisers reach the perfect customer.
articles.abstract: To grab some of TV’s ad dollars, the social network is trying to help advertisers reach the perfect customer.
articles.lead_paragraph: Joao Rodrigues had been listening and holding his tongue. For a day and a half, brand managers, ad agency creative types and Facebook strategists had gathered in airy conference rooms and around cafeteria tables in Facebook’s Madison Avenue offices, filling up whiteboards and scratch pads with one heartfelt or clever tagline after another.

articles.headline: Airstrike Near U.N. School Kills 10 as Israel Shifts Troops in Gaza
articles.snippet: As Israel began to redeploy significant numbers of troops away from populated areas of Gaza on Sunday, an Israeli Air Force missile struck near the school entrance.
articles.abstract: As Israel began to redeploy significant numbers of troops away from populated areas of Gaza on Sunday, an Israeli Air Force missile struck near the school entrance.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — As Israel began to redeploy significant numbers of its troops away from populated areas of Gaza on Sunday, an Israeli Air Force missile struck near the entrance of a United Nations school sheltering displaced Palestinians in Rafah, killing 10 people and wounding 35 others and drawing a new round of international condemnation.
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger and Fares Akram

articles.headline: A News Giant Going It Alone
articles.snippet: The Tribune Company’s publishing unit, including eight well-known newspapers, will venture forth as an independent entity in troubled times, led by Jack Griffin.
articles.abstract: The Tribune Company’s publishing unit, including eight well-known newspapers, will venture forth as an independent entity in troubled times, led by Jack Griffin.
articles.lead_paragraph: After spending years in the shadow of bankruptcy proceedings, management turmoil and its more prominent broadcasting stations, the Tribune Company’s publishing division, including well-known newspapers like The Los Angeles Times and The Chicago Tribune, is striking out on its own.

articles.headline: A Web Guerrilla Breaking News From the Jungle
articles.snippet: Glenn Greenwald, who broke the Edward Snowden story, is one of the world’s most wired reporters, but he operates from a redoubt in Rio with shaky web access.
articles.abstract: Glenn Greenwald, who broke the Edward Snowden story, is one of the world’s most wired reporters, but he operates from a redoubt in Rio with shaky web access.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — On approaching Glenn Greenwald’s home office high in the jungle-encrusted mountains above Rio de Janeiro, all is tranquil, bucolic even. A gurgling stream at the entrance frames the idyll.

articles.headline: Wealth Managers Enlist Spy Tools to Map Portfolios
articles.snippet: Companies like Addepar are using data-filtering techniques honed at spy agencies to help track and value clients’ diverse holdings.
articles.abstract: Companies like Addepar are using data-filtering techniques honed at spy agencies to help track and value clients’ diverse holdings.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — Some of the engineers who used to help the Central Intelligence Agency solve problems have moved on to another challenge: determining the value of every conceivable investment in the world.

articles.headline: As Oysters Die, Climate Policy Goes on the Stump
articles.snippet: In Washington State, where scientists say a rise in carbon levels is killing shellfish, Gov. Jay Inslee is working to pass climate change policies, aided by a billionaire friend.
articles.abstract: In Washington State, where scientists say a rise in carbon levels is killing shellfish, Gov. Jay Inslee is working to pass climate change policies, aided by a billionaire friend.
articles.lead_paragraph: OLYMPIA, Wash. — Billions of baby oysters in the Pacific inlets here are dying and Gov. Jay Inslee of Washington is busy spreading the bad news.

articles.headline: Nickelodeon’s Digital Generation
articles.snippet: The 36-year-old network is making a broad effort to discover, develop and disseminate shows for children who barely distinguish among a television set, a laptop, a tablet and a mobile phone.
articles.abstract: The 36-year-old network is making a broad effort to discover, develop and disseminate shows for children who barely distinguish among a television set, a laptop, a tablet and a mobile phone.
articles.lead_paragraph: Meet Olly Timbers. Olly, an orange-haired 10-year-old boy, says he likes “rum raisin ice cream, going on adventures, getting scratched just behind his elbow and also other kinds of ice cream.”

articles.headline: Neighbors Say Barn Weddings Raise a Rumpus
articles.snippet: A boom in barn weddings is pitting owners who say they need the revenue against neighbors who worry about noisy intrusions on rural life.
articles.abstract: A boom in barn weddings is pitting owners who say they need the revenue against neighbors who worry about noisy intrusions on rural life.
articles.lead_paragraph: GRANT, Minn. — For legions of young couples, there is no wedding venue more desirable than a barn in the country, with its unfussy vibe, picturesque setting and rural authenticity.

articles.headline: Affordable Housing Draws Middle Class to Inland Cities
articles.snippet: Pushed out of big coastal cities by the price of homes and a lack of easy credit, many Americans are gravitating toward places like Oklahoma City.
articles.abstract: Pushed out of big coastal cities by the price of homes and a lack of easy credit, many Americans are gravitating toward places like Oklahoma City.
articles.lead_paragraph: OKLAHOMA CITY — Americans have never hesitated to pack up the U-Haul in search of the big time, a better job or just warmer weather. But these days, domestic migrants are increasingly driven by the quest for cheaper housing.

articles.headline: Questions of Weapons and Warnings in Past Barrage on a Gaza Shelter
articles.snippet: An examination of the strike Wednesday at a U.N. shelter in Gaza suggests that Israeli troops paid little heed to warnings to safeguard such sites and may have used heavy artillery not designed for precision use.
articles.abstract: An examination of the strike Wednesday at a U.N. shelter in Gaza suggests that Israeli troops paid little heed to warnings to safeguard such sites and may have used heavy artillery not designed for precision use.
articles.lead_paragraph: JABALIYA, Gaza Strip — An examination of an Israeli barrage that put a line of at least 10 shells through a United Nations school sheltering displaced Palestinians here last week suggests that Israeli troops paid little heed to warnings to safeguard such sites and may have unleashed weapons inappropriate for urban areas despite rising alarm over civilian deaths.
articles.byline: By Ben Hubbard and Jodi Rudoren

articles.headline: Why Is the Economy Still Weak? Blame These Five Sectors
articles.snippet: The United States is still producing around $800 billion a year less in goods and services than it would if it the economy were at full health.
articles.abstract: The United States is still producing around $800 billion a year less in goods and services than it would if it the economy were at full health.
articles.lead_paragraph: The economy keeps underperforming. Yes, new G.D.P. data last week were better than expected. But the United States is still producing around $800 billion a year less in goods and services than it would if the economy were at full health, and as a result millions of people aren’t working who would be if conditions were better.
